content:
the driving god
does a track day.

A foie gras car
with a luncheon meat badge.

And we try to set
a new land speed record.

Hello! And we start tonight
with some good news

because I've finally found
an advantage to being over 40.

Yes, hair sprouts out of your ears
and, yes, hangovers last a fortnight,
but, all you youngsters,

the only chance you get to drive a
Subaru Impreza and a Mitsubishi Evo VIII
is on your PlayStations.

Whereas me, with my wise
shoulders and my hairy ears,

I'm allowed by the insurance
companies to take them to

the best driving country
in the world.
Scotland.

These cars were born in the rough
and tumble he-man world of rallying.

With their turbo-charged engines
and their four-wheel drive systems,

they grip and they go
and they stop so ferociously

that you're just left
absolutely breathless.

In the real world
with bumps and hedges,

low-nosed, wide-bottomed
Ferraris and Porsches

couldn't hope to keep up
with either of them.
They are astonishing.

And yet they're both relatively
inexpensive Japanese saloon cars.

They've both got four doors,
they've both got big boots,

they're both as reliable as a Swiss
bus driver's Austrian pacemaker.

What more could you
possibly want?

Let's deal with the
Subaru first.

The old model, the one with the
silly headlamps, was a bit of a softy.

The new one has a more
attractive face but don't be fooled.

The steering is quicker
and the suspension is tougher.

They've made it harder,
edgier,

less of a car,
more of a bar room brawler.

It's a different story
with the Mitsubishi Evo VIII.

The old Evo VII was like a Mafia
hit man, without the compassion.

At first glance, it seems they've
made the Evo VIII even more hard-core.

It's lighter and its gearbox
has six speeds rather than five.
In actual fact though,

they've made it a little bit
softer and quieter.

They've even given it a proper
big fuel tank.

The old one used to have
a Zippo in the back.

You were only able to go four
inches before you ran out of petrol.
So the Subaru's been beefed up

and the Mitsubishi's
been watered down.

It seems then that these two
cars have met in the middle.

And that means I have to go out
there into the bigness of Scotland
and find out which one's best.

Sometimes, you know,
this job is very, very good.

Nothing prepares you
for the shock

when you first take this thing
round a corner. Take a test drive.
Honestly, take a test drive.

You will not believe
how much grip there is.
You just won't.

This Subaru is a hugely
manly experience.

The noise it makes, it's got a macho
gearbox, it's got macho steering.
It even smells of man,
the essence of burnt clutch.

Splash it on all over before going
out at night for a curry and a fight.

The Mitsubishi
is much more technical.

It's got an Active Centre
Differential which moves the power

to the front wheels or the back wheels
depending on which have the most grip.

All I have to do is tell it whether
we're on tarmac, gravel or snow.

And then it's got something
called Super Active Yaw Control

which moves the power
from side to side.

Sometimes then, in a really big
corner, when you're really hammering,
this car is one-wheel drive.

So I can sum them up
like this.

The Mitsubishi is like an F16
fighter, light and highly manoeuvrable.

The Subaru is more like
an F15. A fighter bomber.

As far as power's concerned, both
of them get close to 150 miles an hour

and both do naught to 60
in under five seconds.

You can't split them
on looks either.

And inside both have willfully flimsy
interiors that are lifted only by the big seats

and the buttons for spraying
cold water on the intercoolers.

On the outside, the Subaru tries to lighten
up with its pink and gold jewellery.

But both these cars really
are shamelessly aggressive.

Look at the scoop
on this bonnet.

And they seem to have given
the Evo so many steroids,

it's started to grow
out of its own body.

You know what these cars
should be called, don't you?

The Mitsubishi
"Did you spill my pint?"

And the Subaru,
"You Outside Now!"

Trying to decide
which is best is hard.

They're both spoon-bendingly, hallucinogenically,
law-breakingly mad and absurd.

On a wide open road like this,
the nimbler Mitsubishi wins.

But when things get narrow and
bumpy, the Evo really does turn into a jet.

On a difficult road like this,
the Impreza feels more planted.
So, which would I buy?

Ooh, I can't give you
an answer now.
I'm having far too much fun.

So, Jeremy, what did you
discover after your

unnecessarily
long trip to Scotland?

- Nothing.
- Right.

It's impossible to choose
between these two cars.

There's no tangible reason why
you'd take one rather than the other.

The only thing I will say is
that when we finished filming

and I just had to drive
back to the hotel

I always found myself
getting into the Subaru.

Know exactly what you mean, couldn't
tell you why. I prefer the Impreza.
Always have, no idea why.

It's like, you know, I prefer
dark chocolate to milk chocolate.

I prefer Bedford
to Bruce Forsyth.
Right.

Well, let's see if we can find
out if there is any real differences

between them
on our test track.

So, ladies and gentlemen,
please say mushi mushi to Stig-san.

So first up, the Impreza STi.
This is the tweet one, remember.
And... Oh, dear.

Ah! An emotional Stig
this week, round Chicago.

Now, at the limit, this car does
under-steer so will that slow him down?
It is looking good so far.

Oh! He is... I reckon...
He is running wide there.

Into the penultimate corner. Come on,
Stig, keep it tight. We need a good time.

And there's under-steer there. Loads of
under-steer and he goes round the finishing line!
Now what about the Evo VIII?

In the interests of fairness, I
should point out this isn't the car

that Jeremy drove in Scotland.
It's the 301 horsepower FQ version.

25 more than standard
and one more than the Subaru.

Looking very tidy
round Chicago.

No trace of under-steer at all as it
smoothly powers through the Hammerhead.
Good Lord!

Screaming out of the Follow Through,
over a second faster than the Subaru.

In the first set of
the Mitsubishi.

Will it beat it?
Over the finish line.

Kicking up dust
through Gambon, right then.

The times. I have them here.
Are you ready?

The Impreza STi, first
of all, did it in 1:30.1,

which puts it there, faster than
the Aston, just behind the Z8.
That is a very good time.

And how much faster is that
than the Impreza

that we had in the last
series, the old model?

It's just under
one and a half seconds.

- One and a half seconds faster?
- I know. It's very fast.

But get this,
the Mitsubishi Evo VIII,

- Can you reach?
- I can get that, Jeremy.

Quicker than the Lamborghini
Murcielago?

That's astonishing.
That is incredible!
That's a very fast car.

So if you want to go
round a track quickly
you take the Evo VIII.

- But which would you choose?
- Impreza. No idea why.

Neither of these cars, or indeed
any of them, really, on our power board

find much favour among
The Guardian set, let's say.

Whenever I go to a dinner party,
I sit down, the person next to me
always starts off by saying,

"Please, will you go
and sit next to someone else?"
The second thing they say is,

"We've got a 70 mile an hour
speed limit in this country.

"Why do we have
such fast cars?"

Well, the thing is, is that you
can drive these cars quickly.

Because all of the
country's race tracks,

Silverstone, Brands Hatch,
Cadwell, Oulton Park, Scotland...

All of them now run
things called track days

where you take your own car
along and drive it as fast as you want.

I always fancied going to a track
day but I needed the right car.
Well, fortunately, this month,

Peugeot have launched this
180 brake horsepower version
of their 206 GTI.

Bedford Autodrome,
PalmerSport day.
All over the country,

people are queuing up to come to
these "run what you brung" track days.

And so, make way
for the Peugeot 206 GTI 180.

There's always a lot of expectations
surrounding a new hot hatch from Peugeot.

It's because of the pedigree.
It's because of the 205 GTI.

After all,
the 205 was an icon.

It was one of the great
hot hatches of the 1980s.
Indeed, of all time.

Yes, don't worry. That was me
and not the car running out of talent.

Because the 206 is well-balanced
and has masses of grip.

And the good news is that engine has
given it just the extra oomph it needed.

Should probably take
the stuff off now.
Not far from the truth.

It'll do naught to 60 in 7.1 seconds
and can reach 142 miles an hour.

That's fast, and I think the 205
would be proud of its offspring.

But ultimately, the 206 is
at heart, a civilised road car.

Unfortunately, I've brought
a knife to a gun fight.

Because the whole point of a
track day is to leave civilised roads,

and, let's be honest, civilised
road behaviour behind.

Why do you
do it then?

Um, simply because there's too
many damn speed cameras around.

And I think it's a way of venting.
One, your passion to drive fast

because you can't
in this country any more,

and why the hell buy a car that'll
do 155 miles an hour and not use it?

It's easy to see why these "run what
you brung" track days are booming.

You don't need a race license
and you don't have to

join a race series
and follow a race calendar.

It's just you,
your car and your helmet.
Look at this guy.

2 grands worth of Honda Prelude
and he thinks he's Jenson Button.

I have never seen
such an ordinary car
take so much abuse.

- What was your...
- Thank you!

- What was your mission?
- Thank you.
Yeah, it was to have good fun,

drive it as hard as I could and
sort of drive the wheels off it.

That takes serious effort.
You have ruined it!

It's... Yeah,
they were new last week.

I should've got some
secondhand ones, shouldn't I?

Running an old knacker
is actually quite a good idea

because, not surprisingly, track days are
not covered by your ordinary road insurance.

If I wanted to get insurance, it's probably
going to be around £120 for the day.

So, I usually just go out
without it.
If you broke it though,

you push it off the circuit to a
road, stick it in a ditch and go,
"Look! What happened?"

- I've heard that happens.
- Yes, I've heard...

I've seen cars pushed out
onto the road.

That 206 GTI had given me
track-day fever,

but it didn't
provide the cure.
I needed stronger medicine.

This is the Palmer Jaguar,
a track day thunderbolt.

And a more fitting remedy for a
man who had once proclaimed...
I am a driving god!
Oh, my goodness!
This is a properly quick car.

It uses the 3-litre V6
out of Jaguar's X-type,

gives it about 300 brake horsepower
and it weighs about 600 kilos.
That is very, very light.

And it means
it's very, very fast.

It really can travel
at some incredible speeds.
Straight up to 120, 130.

Absolutely awesome power
in this thing.

Turn it in far here. Use that torque.
The low-down power. Come on!
Yes!

Ooh! I might well have really
overcooked that.
This is amazing!
Once more!

If I'm not a driving god, this
is a car fit for one, at least.

So the driving god
spinning off there

at what I suspect was
probably five miles an hour.

Now, these track days are
such big business these days,

that there are lots of
companies who are making cars

specifically designed
for the purpose.

They're basically racers with
number plates and indicators

so you can take them
on the road.

This Palmer Jag
is one of them.

But it costs £47,000,
and that is quite a lot.

Don't worry though, because there are lots
of others which are a little bit cheaper.

So, that's the stats. Now let's
see which is fastest on the track.

So, here's the cars
in reverse order.

In fifth place,
the Lotus Elise at 1:28.2.

In fourth, it's the
Caterham at 1:25 flat.

In third, the Atom
with 1:24 flat.

And in second place,
the Westfield at 1:23.2.

And first, the amazing
Radical. 1:19.8.

Right, the news, and we begin this
week with a story about advertising.

Um, I have no idea how much
advertising agencies charge big companies

to come up with snappy
strap lines for products.

Must be millions and millions
and millions of pounds.

I mean, the classic case in
point for me was Sainsbury's.

They went to the ad agency and they
said, "We want to get across a message

"that we sell good food,
value for money

"and it'd be nice to get the
name of the company in as well."
And the ad agency said,

"Right, if you give us a couple of million
quid, we'll go to Mauritius for a month."

And they came back with, "Good
food costs less at Sainsbury's."

- I could have thought of that.
- Yeah.

- It's not that clever, really.
- Or, "Coke is it."

Coke... How much did they pay
for "Coke is it."

- Yeah.
- But, this week,

I think I've come across an
ad which just trumps the lot.

You ready to see it? It's
for the new Lexus RX300.

Here it is. There's the car,
and the advert for it is:
"It changes everything."

That is a big claim,
isn't it?

I don't want to go home tonight
and find my front doors moved

and that all my children are badgers
and that I'm married to Frank Bruno.

I don't want it
to change everything.

This'll be a gardening program and we
shouldn't be talking about that anyway.

Well, exactly, and do you know
the thing is, is that you know those.

- Advertising Standards Authority...
- Yes.

They always say you've got to
be... What are they? Truthful...

It's decent, honest,
legal, truthful.
So, that advert must be true.

That'd be great.
You could buy the Lexus

and then you'd wake up the next day
and it'd have changed into a Jaguar.

All right, I've got sad news.
Okay, this is sad news.
You don't know what it is yet.

That's a blind date noise,
isn't it?
It was a horrible noise.

Uh, I thought they were
deflating the entire audience.

- Collapsing.
- What's the sad news?
The sad news is this.
Right, diesel engines.

There were only three manufacturers
who managed to hold on to sense

and not put diesel engines
in their car.

- They were Honda. Well, they went and did it.
- They've gone.
Saab, weakened and did it.

The last one has announced officially, they've
weakened, they've gone, and it's Jaguar.

- Oh no!
- Aw!
I know! It's terrible.
They're putting a...

You all right, Jeremy?
You're quite nasty.

That is a horrific
piece of news.

Well, they're doing a V6 one
in the S-type,

and there's a little four cylinder
diesel going into the X-type,

which, of course,
has nothing to do with Ford.

Oh, no, of course. Jaguar,
yeah, no, it won't be a Ford engine.

I want to make that absolutely plain.
It's a Jaguar engine in every way.

Yeah, but if you pick away at
Jaguar, it might say "ord" underneath.

I don't know where they
put a sticker on it.

But, I just have
worries about this.
Jaguar is stealthy, sleek...

Is it going to work?
Have a look at this.

We've got one in
to have a look at

and we'll get an idea
if it's going to work.

- It's Stig.
- Yeah.
Oh, dear.

That's simply
not going to work, is it?

Yeah, I... It loses something,
doesn't it?

Oh, beautiful.
Just hearing it...
That is not going to work.

And, do you know the
worst thing about this is,

is Jaguar was working,
we know, on an F-type,

a two-seater modern day
E-type

and they cancelled
that project

because they'd spent all
their money on a diesel engine.
Don't do a diesel!

- Please!
- Oh, dear.

Now of course, the big news of the
week that's been in all the papers is...

We'll report here
from The Observer,

"Drivers are facing the biggest revolution
in the history of British motoring."

- It's the Lexus again. It's changed everything!
- Yes!

The thing is that Alistair Darling,
who is the Transport Secretary has said

he doesn't want people all
taking their children to school
at 8:00 in the morning.

Well, now look, Darling, that's
kind of when school starts.

It's not like you take
your child to school

at 3:00 in the morning 'cause
it's nice and quiet.

He hasn't thought all that
through, has he?

So there'll be a lot of headmasters
saying, "Clarkson, you're early."

'Cause Dad arrived in his Jag
diesel, saved a couple of quid there,

and he's dropped me off
at 3:00 in the morning.

The idea is,
Darling is saying,

he is going to use satellites
to track all 24 million drivers,

and that if we use our cars at
popular times, i.e. for going to work,

he's going to
charge us for it.

And you know the most depressing
thing about this, it really is,
and I am quoting now, okay.

"You can't build yourself out of the
problem that we face," said Darling.

"It would be astronomically
expensive, environmentally damaging,

"and I doubt if we could
actually do it."

Now look,
when you have the air ministry

in 1940 watching the Luftwaffe
come over, they didn't say,

"I doubt we can do anything about
that, frankly. We'll just let them..."

Or you know Francis Drake
playing bowls,

"I doubt we can do anything about the
Spanish Armada, there is millions of them."

- It's not the spirit, is it?
- In fact, I have got a simple message,

which I want to deliver in a
new Labour way, to Darling.
Okay. Ready? For your plan?
I've never read such rubbish.

Now, this is a truly
heart-warming tale of British boffins.

They're called Mark and Colin. They've
been in their sheds smoking pipes,
making cups of tea.

And they've been headbanging the
old chestnut, the electric motor car.

They have come up with a
prototype, called the eMotion.

And they say, "We really are at
the cutting edge of technology,

"and aim to lead the way
with a variety of innovations,

"many of which could find an instant
and ready market in the mass production

"of commercially viable
electric cars."
Let's have a look at it.

What a rubbish thing!
It's got a fridge freezer!
And what's this on the top?

Colin said, "Mark, hang on,
we've forgotten the windscreen.

"Could you just lend us
your crash helmet?"

They obviously made it blunt
at one end with a fridge freezer...
A fridge freezer...

Let's make it pointy, then
it's aerodynamic! Look at that!

That's got some way to go before it
becomes a viable four-seater family car.

Do you want to invent something?
Invent another Concorde.

Right now, you know that Subaru and
Mitsubishi film that we showed earlier on?

You're probably looking
at that thinking,

"That scenery, those open
roads, those cars, perfect."
But it wasn't perfect.

And I'm gonna show you an
outtake now, which will explain why.
Caravans.
Get out of the way!

Pull over once in a while!
Once every 300 miles!

Pull over!
Please get out of the way!

Please stay in a hotel
next time!
Please!

Caravans are the bane
of our lives.

So, we decided to set the new
boy, James here, a little task.

Incredibly, the world speed record for
caravans stands at a frankly astonishing
128.86 miles per hour.

But they thought
I could beat that.

Bentwaters. 1.7 miles
of prime Suffolk runway.

If there's anywhere to beat the world speed
record for towing a caravan, it's here.

The car we're using is this
Mitsubishi Evo VII.

Not something normally featured

It will do 130 on its own,
no sweat.

But what it's gonna be like towing
our mobile home, I don't know.

Definitely not gonna be
a holiday!
This is our caravan.

And the rules state that it may not be
aerodynamically modified in any way.

Not so the car, which has power

Its turbo-charged engine
develops 771 bhp.

But that's not the figure we're
interested in. It's torque we want.

And this car has
massive pulling power,
648 pound feet.

Enough to move the mountain

Our driver is Lee here,

And during the run, his hand's
gonna be fairly close to this.

One yank on this,
and it's goodbye caravan.

At over 100 miles per hour, the

taking the car with it.

Or the windows could buckle in

turning the caravan into a huge
parachute. Again flipping the car.

So, our first run,
to test things out.

The caravan's quickly over the
national speed limit.
The Evo VII is pulling hard.

124.9 miles per hour.
That is fantastic.

But then, disaster. It's a high speed
blow-out from the kitchenette window.
You've bust it, you hooligan.

- How fast were you going?
- I think in the car, it was 124.9.

Okay, five miles an hour
and the other side will fall off.

- No. No. Ready?
- That's it.

Right. Didn't quite manage it
that time. But I'm not quitting.

- I'm coming back later and I'm having another go.
- You'd better succeed.

Now, one of the strangest things
about being more than 40 years old,

is that you start to want
contestants on game shows to win.

And stranger still, you start

even when they

Ladies and gentlemen,
Richard Whiteley!
How are you?

- Right.

I've got to be careful
with this, Jeremy.

It's got to be back at Bridlington
first thing tomorrow morning.

I was gonna say, how much do you get

Mind you, I'm no one to talk.
Let's be honest.
Really.

Um... Let's go through
your career history.

- Born up north, yes.
- Born in Yorkshire.

Born in Yorkshire.
Which is fine.

Um... Educated at

- Ooh! Blind date noises.

Launched Channel Four. I think

My first car was a Ford

Two-tone grey.
It was my mother's.

And when I got my first job, I

You also had... I was looking

Yeah.

- Well, it was red

Absolutely beautiful! What

Well, I've got a Jaguar,
actually!

Ah, of course you have.
One of the new ones?

Well, I... Yes. I just... I got

So, it is one of the
new ones with the...
It is.

- Has it got that grill?
- It has.

- It has.
- You're so right, Jeremy. Saw your piece the other day.

It's a fabulous car, but what

Have you stuck

Well, I... I mean I've had...
This is my fifth now...

Or is it my fourth?
My fourth X Jag.

You know, I'm 59 now.
I mean, you know...

- I deserve it, don't I?
- I got nothing against them.

- I've had a Jag for years.
- I just feel a bit of, sort of embarrassed.

I've always
really wanted one.

And the first one I got about
five years ago, I was so proud of it.

Really proud of it.
And there I was...

And one particular day, I was a

- In Leeds.
- Well, it moved from the Tower of London to

this big building,
£45 million.
Most secure building in Leeds.

And I had to go through a process of

so I roared up at one minute
to 11 outside the big glass doors

of the armouries,
nobody around,

uh, opened the door, engine
running, rushed right in to get my pass.

I parked at the front thinking...
I know you're not meant to

park at the front, but I thought,

I went out. I pushed this
big glass door round,

I sort of looked outside and I
saw someone getting in to my car.
And I thought,

"They're terrific, the armouries.
They're valet parking it for me.
"Fantastic."

And then it roared off. It roared
off. And I can tell you, Jeremy.

A Jaguar does do naught to 60 in

- It was nicked?
- It was nicked.

- Did you ever get it back?
- Well, so the story... Well, I got it back.

Yes, I got it back about 10 days
later. It was okay. I mean, they'd...

- They'd used the ashtrays and they'd...
- Oh, no.

And they'd tuned the radio from
Radio 4 to the local commercial station,

so I was a bit
annoyed about that.

You know, I did get it back
and it was okay. But a year later,

I went on some charity visit
to Armley Jail in Leeds,

and we were all there, the great and
the good. We were being shown round

- and they echo, these prisons, have you been in one?
- Yeah.

- Have you?
- Yeah, a French one.

- This is...
- But we won't go there!

We were looking round, the
great and the good of Leeds,

and from the galleries high up,
someone yelled down, can I...

- Can I do this? Can I yell... They said...
- Yell.

"Northern Whiteley,
you fat!"
